My angle is that people who need columns of numbers to line up are more likely to be people who don’t know to choose between different number styles; and people who mind badly spaced (read: tabular) numerals are more likely to be people who do know about alternates. So tabular is more fool-proof as a default; but there’s no reason to make them lining; plus making them lining makes the spacing even worse; ergo: tabular oldstyle is the best default (for a typical text face at least), assuming other styles are available. Oh, and hybrid. If other styles are not available, I would probably go for the stinky old standard, tabular lining. But: 3/4 height (except if the caps happen to be unusually short).

Thanks Paul, and at the risk of boring people. I’ll repeat it here:

The default should be tabular lining.

Tabular, because proportional figures really screw up a tab setting, while tabular are OK (though not ideal) in a text setting — and both situations are likely to occur for users who are not aware of the options.

Lining, for the same reason: old style figures are just too quaint for most tabular settings, especially when leading is tight, and ascenders and descenders create too much vertical flow.

Tabular settings are not confined to financial or mathematical pages, but occur in many commercial uses, such as price lists and phone numbers in business stationery and contact information.  
A very common setting where tabular figures are much better is for the numbering of a list of items: once you get to the “teens”, it looks awful with proportional “1”s that don’t line up.

\*\*\*

Although I agree with chester over what looks “right”, and recognize that sophisticated typographers (at a design studio, say) may prefer OSF in a pre-1800 type genre, the problem is that the typographer is often not the end user, as when a type is specified for a corporate identity and third parties such as sales promotion companies, or the client’s in-house art department, assume that responsibility. They are less likely to be typographically astute enough to change proportional to lining when required, and may well be using software that doesn’t even give them the option to change the default.

Agreed on the tabular, but not on the lining. Besides the fact
